<p><img src="https://31.media.tumblr.com/f877983c4f5dc185bb3b4a0e8611b711/tumblr_inline_n7nk1gSP181rr2wit.jpg"/></p>

<p><a href="http://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/51880-0-23-5-Engine-Ignitor-%28V3-2-Pressurizing-RPM-MFD-Boil-off-acc-Feb-12%29"><img src="https://31.media.tumblr.com/8c14905c41670790e16d832aaf1bf93e/tumblr_inline_n7noh3qHVY1rr2wit.png"/></a></p>

<p></p>

<p><strong>HoneyFox</strong>'s <a href="http://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/51880-0-23-5-Engine-Ignitor-%28V3-2-Pressurizing-RPM-MFD-Boil-off-acc-Feb-12%29"><strong>ENGINE IGNITOR</strong></a> brings more strategy to your game of <em>KSP</em> by limiting the amount of times you can ignite your engine. The difficulty in handling your engine will also be ratcheted up under zero-g, too. Those aren’t all the features, either. There’s a more fully fleshed out list and downloads <a href="http://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/51880-0-23-5-Engine-Ignitor-%28V3-2-Pressurizing-RPM-MFD-Boil-off-acc-Feb-12%29"><strong>HERE</strong></a>.</p>
Cool! That's a really nice mod, nice to see it here

It is a nice mod, I use it with Real Solar System / Realism Overhaul.

One thing -- could you change the post to say "microgravity" instead of "zero-g"? Zero gravity isn't possible because the force of gravity is infinite. Microgravity is still somewhat misleading but it's a better term than zero-g. Technically, weightlessness would be the best term but it might not sound right in a sentence.
A very interesting mod, but I'd need to run it in a separate KSP instance. Too much stuff that I do would be completely broken by this!

It is a nice mod, I use it with Real Solar System / Realism Overhaul.

One thing -- could you change the post to say "microgravity" instead of "zero-g"? Zero gravity isn't possible because the force of gravity is infinite. Microgravity is still somewhat misleading but it's a better term than zero-g. Technically, weightlessness would be the best term but it might not sound right in a sentence.

Zero-G simply means, in this context, that you're feeling no force of gravity, because you're in freefall. I don't think it's a big deal. It's sort of like the word "theory." Everybody thinks it means "hypothesis," but in physics and math it means a proven concept. In informal writing, you have to understand the word differently.
It's an interesting idea for a mod that I will never be interested in personally. I can see how some would like it, not my cup of tea though.

It's an interesting idea for a mod that I will never be interested in personally. I can see how some would like it, not my cup of tea though.

Yeah, some people like it, but its one of those things where you have to be a little masochistic for it. Not mine either.
Science n00b question: Why is this the case in real life?

Zero-G simply means, in this context, that you're feeling no force of gravity, because you're in freefall. I don't think it's a big deal. It's sort of like the word "theory." Everybody thinks it means "hypothesis," but in physics and math it means a proven concept. In informal writing, you have to understand the word differently.

Actually, "Zero-G" also means that in all contexts. It doesn't stand for zero gravity but for zero gravities. Meaning, the force ("Gs") you feel is zero. You can be in zero-G during diving in an airplane, for instance, or anytime in a freefall situation.

Science n00b question: Why is this the case in real life?

Which bit? "Why do most engines only light once?" Because they are designed that way - making them so they can light several times means adding extra components, extra ways things can go wrong, extra cost and extra weight to carry into space. For a first stage booster, in Real Life that's not necessary. Some engines *do* need to fire multiple times, such as the Shuttle Orbital Manoeuvring System, and they need special designs to enable that.

If you mean "why do engines not fire in zero G?", the answer is that there is nothing to make sure there is any fuel up against the fuel exit port of the fuel tank - it can literally have all sloshed to the wrong end of the tank, so all the engine gets is fuel vapour. SO engineers add some sort of low-thrust system that pushes the rocket forwards gently, so the fuel moves backwards, and the engines can then suck fuel and not vapour.

Because they are designed that way - making them so they can light several times means adding extra components, extra ways things can go wrong, extra cost and extra weight to carry into space. For a first stage booster, in Real Life that's not necessary. Some engines *do* need to fire multiple times, such as the Shuttle Orbital Manoeuvring System, and they need special designs to enable that.

If you mean "why do engines not fire in zero G?", the answer is that there is nothing to make sure there is any fuel up against the fuel exit port of the fuel tank - it can literally have all sloshed to the wrong end of the tank, so all the engine gets is fuel vapour. SO engineers add some sort of low-thrust system that pushes the rocket forwards gently, so the fuel moves backwards, and the engines can then suck fuel and not vapour.

I guess both. Thanks. This is good as a mod, but I don't think it would fit very well in the stock game.

Actually, "Zero-G" also means that in all contexts. It doesn't stand for zero gravity but for zero gravities. Meaning, the force ("Gs") you feel is zero. You can be in zero-G during diving in an airplane, for instance, or anytime in a freefall situation.

If you're freefalling in an atmosphere, wouldn't that technically not be a weightless experience because of the drag slowing the fall?

Also, about "zero gravity": "Microgravity is sometimes called 'zero gravity,' but this is misleading."

Source: http://www.nasa.gov/audience/forstudents/5-8/features/what-is-microgravity-58.html#.U6waT_ldVx0

It is a nice mod, I use it with Real Solar System / Realism Overhaul.

One thing -- could you change the post to say "microgravity" instead of "zero-g"? Zero gravity isn't possible because the force of gravity is infinite. Microgravity is still somewhat misleading but it's a better term than zero-g. Technically, weightlessness would be the best term but it might not sound right in a sentence.

I think it's a bit like engineers talking about friction causing re-entry heat. They know it's actually air compression. We know that too, but many other people wouldn't get it, so they use a slightly-incorrect-but-more-widely-understood term.
